docs.title: Welcome to Edit Masters
docs.text:
Edit Masters is your academic learning space — a curated resource hub for developing editing, writing, and research communication skills.

Whether you're a student, researcher, or editor, this platform provides structured, day-by-day lessons designed to improve your clarity, coherence, and confidence in academic writing.

docs.title: About Us
docs.text:
At Edit Masters, we believe that effective writing is a skill that can be learned through practice and precision. Our mission is to provide reliable, practical, and well-structured materials to guide your academic journey.

📚 Start Learning - Beginners Lessons - Intermediate Lessons

docs.title: Assignment 1
docs.text:
Let's try an edit assignment! Pick a sample edit for the field you are associated with, edit it, and email it to your PoC.

Before you start editing the file, please turn on Track Changes.

docs.title: 🧪 Choose Your Quiz
docs.text:
Click on the link that best represents your field:

  • HUMANITIES
  • LIFE SCIENCES AND MEDICINE
  • PHYSICAL SCIENCES

docs.title: Common Errors: Sentence Structure - Assignments
docs.text:
An editor is an expert when it comes to analyzing and restructuring modifiers and complements in a sentence. To develop these skill, please do these assignments. You can use a notebook or MS Word to write your answers down. There are no right or wrong answers. Just practice. Please refer to AN ADVANCED ENGLISH GRAMMAR for reference.

2.1.1. Point out the adjectives used as modifiers of the subject. Substitute for each an adjective phrase; an adjective clause.

  1. Standing in the door was a tearful child.

  2. A tall Scot shut off my view.

  3. An iron mask concealed the prisoner’s face.

  4. Honorable men pay their debts.

  5. A tumble-down shed stood in the hollow.

  6. A three-cornered hat was cocked over one of his ears.

  7. The American Indians are becoming extinct.

  8. An experienced stenographer should spell correctly.

  9. A deep fosse or ditch was drawn round the whole building.

  10. The royal army was assembled at Salisbury.

  11. The mid-day meal was excellent.

  12. The morning mist lies heavy upon yonder chain of islands.

2.1.2. Construct sentences, using the following adjective phrases as modifiers of the subject and of the predicate:

of great height; in a red hat; with black hair; from Cairo; to Indianapolis; from India; with high gables; of brilliant plumage; on the rear platform; in a state of intense agitation; between the two ships; over the mountain; on the summit of the tower.

2.1.3 Point out all the adverbs used to modify the simple predicate. Substitute for each an adverbial phrase or clause.

  1. The witness chose his words deliberately.

  2. The old man moved slowly down the street.

  3. I carefully avoided making that promise.

  4. Do not speak so loud.

  5. I am eagerly looking forward to your visit.

  6. That golf ball must have hit him hard.

  7. Allan has played in public twice.

  8. I shall call you early.

  9. We often see your eccentric friend.

  10. The priest shook his head doubtfully.

  11. Your father barely escaped drowning.

  12. The next morning Chester awoke late.

  13. The accident happened here.

  14. The captain had gone below.

  15. Marion refuses to go by coach unless she can sit outside.

  16. Frank left home three years ago, and has not been heard from since.

  17. Look yonder and tell us where the path lies.

  18. We were then presented to Governor Gore.

  19. I have not been there since April.

  20. Bruce was afterward ashamed of his discouragement.

  21. The sun will soon set.

  22. You are expected to arrive in good season hereafter.

  23. Alice cannot spell correctly.

  24. The Indian suddenly disappeared.

  25. The girl laughed carelessly.

  26. The moose fell heavily to the earth.

  27. He passionately longs to see Italy.

  28. All foreigners seem to speak rapidly.

  29. Edith listened attentively.

docs.title: 🎓 Course Introduction and Pre-Test
docs.text: Welcome to the Beginners Lessons! This course will help you strengthen fundamental aspects of English grammar and vocabulary before moving on to more advanced areas of editing, such as comprehension and technical accuracy.

docs.title: 🧭 Let’s Begin
docs.text:
Before you dive in, start with a quick pre-test to assess your current level.

You’ll be directed to a quiz on basic grammar and word choice. Please read all instructions carefully before beginning.

💡 Tip: Enter your EditMasters email ID in the quiz form when prompted.

docs.title: 🧩 Quiz Instructions
docs.text:
Avoid extra spaces in your answers. - ❌ (the ) → This will be marked wrong. (Notice the extra space after the word) - ✅ (the) → Correct

Use punctuation marks, not words, for punctuation answers. - ❌ comma - ✅ ,

Complete all questions before submitting the form.

docs.title: 🧪 Choose Your Quiz
docs.text:
Click on the link that best represents your field:

  • HUMANITIES
  • LIFE SCIENCES AND MEDICINE
  • PHYSICAL SCIENCES

Ready? Let’s begin your journey toward mastering editing and proofreading skills with EditMasters. 🚀

docs.title: Sentences

docs.title: Substitutes For The Parts Of Speech
docs.text: Your browser does not support the video tag.

docs.title: 🗣️ The Sentence
docs.text: !!! note "Overview" Language is thought expressed in words. To express thought, words are combined into sentences. A sentence is a group of words which expresses a complete thought.

docs.title: ✳️ Types of Sentences
docs.text:
• Declarative — asserts something as a fact. • Interrogative — asks a question. • Imperative — expresses a command or request. • Exclamatory — expresses an emotion, such as surprise or grief, in the form of an exclamation or cry.

A declarative, interrogative, or imperative sentence may also be exclamatory.

docs.title: 🔤 Subject and Predicate
docs.text:
!!! tip "Structure of a Sentence" • Every sentence consists of a subject and a predicate.

• The subject of a sentence designates the person, place or thing that the sentence is about; the predicate is that which is said of the subject.

• The simple subject of a sentence is a noun or pronoun. The simple predicate of a sentence is a verb or verb phrase.

• The simple subject is the main noun or pronoun that the sentence is about. When combined with all the other words that explain, modify or complete its meaning, it forms the complete subject.

• The simple predicate is the main verb or verb phrase that asserts something about the subject. When combined with all the other words that explain, modify or complete its meaning, it forms the complete predicate.

• A compound subject or predicate consists of two or more simple subjects or predicates, joined, when necessary, by conjunctions.

• Either the subject or the predicate, or both, may be compound.

docs.title: 🧱 The Parts of Speech
docs.text: In accordance with their use in a sentence, words are divided into eight parts of speech: nouns, pronouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, prepositions, conjunctions, and interjections.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Nouns and Pronouns
docs.text:
(1) A noun is the name of a person, place or thing.

(2) A pronoun is a word used instead of a noun. It designates a person, place or thing without naming it.

Nouns and pronouns are called substantives. The substantive to which a pronoun refers is called its antecedent.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Adjectives
docs.text:
(3) An adjective is a word that describes or limits a substantive. This is usually done by indicating a specific quality.

An adjective is said to “belong” to the substantive that it describes or limits.

An adjective that describes is called a descriptive adjective; one that points out or designates is called a definitive adjective.

An article is considered an adjective. ‘A’ or ‘an’ are indefinite articles used to denote a nonspecific substantive. ‘The’ is a definite article used to denote a specific substantive.

docs.title: 3️⃣ Verbs
docs.text:
(4) A verb is a word that asserts something (usually an action) concerning a person, place or thing.

Some verbs express a state or condition rather than an action. A group of words that is used as a verb is called a verb phrase.

Certain verbs, when used to make verb-phrases, are called auxiliary (or aiding) verbs, because they help other verbs to express an action or a state.

Is (in its various forms) and several other verbs may be used to frame sentences in which a word or words in the predicate describe or define the subject. In such sentences, is and other verbs used for the same purpose are called copulative (or linking) verbs.

The infinitive is a verb form that can act as a noun or a modifier and is commonly preceded by the preposition to, which is indicative of the infinitive form.

The participle is a verb form that has no subject and acts like an adjective. It expresses an action or a state in such a way as to describe or limit a substantive.

A participle is said to “belong” to the substantive that it describes or limits.

The two main types of participles are present participles and past participles, based on the time that they denote.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Adverbs
docs.text:
(5) An adverb is a word that modifies a verb, an adjective, or another adverb.

A word or group of words that changes or modifies the meaning of another word is called a modifier. Adjectives and adverbs are both modifiers.

docs.title: 5️⃣ Prepositions, Conjunctions, and Interjections
docs.text:
(6) A preposition is a word placed before a substantive to show its relation to another word in the sentence. The substantive that follows a preposition is called its object.

(7) A conjunction connects words or groups of words.

(8) An interjection is a cry or other exclamatory sound expressing an emotion, such as surprise, anger or pleasure.

docs.title: 🧾 Additional Notes
docs.text: • The meaning of a word in a sentence determines the part of speech to which it belongs. • The same word may sometimes be one part of speech, and sometimes another, particularly with infinitives and participles. • Inflection is a change in the form of a word indicating a difference in its meaning. A word thus changed in form is said to be inflected. • The inflection of a substantive is called its declension; that of an adjective or an adverb its comparison; that of a verb its conjugation.

docs.title: 🧩 Phrases
docs.text:
!!! abstract "Definition" A phrase is a group of connected words that does not contain a subject or a predicate.

A phrase is equivalent to a part of speech:

• A phrase used as a noun is called a noun phrase. • A phrase used as a verb is called a verb phrase. • A phrase used as an adjective is called an adjective phrase. • A phrase used as an adverb is called an adverbial phrase.

Adjective or adverbial phrases consisting of a preposition and its object, with or without other words, are called prepositional phrases.

docs.title: 🔗 Clauses
docs.text:
A clause is a group of words that forms part of a sentence and contains a subject and a predicate.

A clause used as a part of speech is called a subordinate clause. All other clauses are called independent clauses.

Clauses of the same order or rank are said to be coordinate clauses.

docs.title: 📘 Types of Sentences
docs.text: • Sentences may be simple, compound, complex, or compound-complex. • A simple sentence has only one subject and one predicate, either or both of which may be compound. • A compound sentence consists of two or more independent coordinate clauses, which may or may not be joined by conjunctions. • A complex sentence consists of two or more clauses, one of which is independent and the rest subordinate. • A compound sentence in which one or more of the coordinate clauses are complex is called a compound-complex sentence.

docs.title: 🧠 Subordinate Clauses
docs.text:
• Subordinate clauses, like phrases, are used as parts of speech. They serve as substitutes for nouns, adjectives, or adverbs. • A subordinate clause that is used as a noun is called a noun (or substantive) clause. • A subordinate clause that modifies a substantive is called an adjective clause. • A subordinate clause that serves as an adverbial modifier is called an adverbial clause.

✅ End of Summary
